metadata.title: Tragedy of the Commons: Two Farmers and Shared Pasture
metadata.description: A classic tragedy of the commons scenario where two farmers sharing a pasture make individually rational decisions that collectively lead to overgrazing and pasture degradation, demonstrating how individual optimization can result in collective harm.
learning_objectives: Understand how individual rational decisions can lead to collective irrationality
Identify the structure of tragedy of the commons systems
Recognize how shared resources create competing reinforcing loops
Explore interventions to prevent commons tragedies
metadata.author: Systems Thinking Education Team
metadata.layout_strategy: Place the two farmers reinforcing loops on the left side of the diagram. Place 'Farmer A''s R loop in the upper left. Place 'Farmer B' in the lower left. Place a 'Total Activity' in the center of the left side. Place 'Pasture Health' in the exact center (0,0). Place 'Overgrazing Limit' on right side in the middle.

nodes.label: Farmer A Cattle Count
nodes.description: Number of cattle that Farmer A grazes on the shared pasture
nodes.measurement: Number of cattle, head count, livestock units

nodes.label: Farmer A Income
nodes.description: Revenue generated by Farmer A from cattle sales and milk production
nodes.measurement: Dollar income per month/year, profit margins

nodes.label: Farmer A Incentive to Add Cattle
nodes.description: Farmer A's motivation to increase herd size based on potential additional income
nodes.measurement: Expected return on investment, profit per additional animal

nodes.label: Farmer B Cattle Count
nodes.description: Number of cattle that Farmer B grazes on the shared pasture
nodes.measurement: Number of cattle, head count, livestock units

nodes.label: Farmer B Income
nodes.description: Revenue generated by Farmer B from cattle sales and milk production
nodes.measurement: Dollar income per month/year, profit margins

nodes.label: Farmer B Incentive to Add Cattle
nodes.description: Farmer B's motivation to increase herd size based on potential additional income
nodes.measurement: Expected return on investment, profit per additional animal

nodes.label: Total Cattle Activity
nodes.description: Combined grazing pressure from both farmers' cattle on the shared pasture
nodes.measurement: Total number of cattle, grazing pressure units, carrying capacity utilization

nodes.label: Pasture Health
nodes.description: Overall condition and sustainability of the shared grazing land
nodes.measurement: Grass coverage percentage, soil quality index, vegetation health metrics

nodes.label: Overgrazing Limit Exceeded
nodes.description: Point at which total grazing pressure exceeds the pasture's sustainable carrying capacity
nodes.measurement: Carrying capacity percentage, sustainability threshold indicators

edges.description: More cattle generate more income for Farmer A
Higher income creates incentive to add even more cattle for additional profit
Strong incentive leads Farmer A to add more cattle to the herd

loops.label: Farmer A Growth Loop
loops.description: Farmer A's cattle generate income, which creates incentive to add more cattle, creating a reinforcing cycle of herd expansion
loops.behavior_pattern: Individual optimization leads to continuous herd growth

loops.label: Farmer B Growth Loop
loops.description: Farmer B's cattle generate income, which creates incentive to add more cattle, creating a reinforcing cycle of herd expansion
loops.behavior_pattern: Individual optimization leads to continuous herd expansion

loops.label: Farmer A Commons Tragedy Loop
loops.description: Farmer A's cattle contribute to overgrazing, which eventually reduces the income that drives expansion, but delays make this balancing effect too weak and too late
loops.behavior_pattern: Long-term negative consequences that are too delayed to prevent short-term optimization

loops.label: Farmer B Commons Tragedy Loop
loops.description: Farmer B's cattle contribute to overgrazing, which eventually reduces the income that drives expansion, but delays make this balancing effect too weak and too late
loops.behavior_pattern: Long-term negative consequences that are too delayed to prevent short-term optimization

leverage_points.title: Implement Collective Pasture Management
leverage_points.description: Create shared governance system that manages total grazing pressure rather than allowing unlimited individual decisions
intervention_strategies: Establish grazing quotas based on carrying capacity
Create shared ownership or management structure
Implement rotational grazing system managed collectively
leverage_points.expected_impact: Prevents tragedy by aligning individual incentives with collective welfare

leverage_points.title: Align Economic Incentives with Sustainability
leverage_points.description: Change payment structure so farmers are rewarded for pasture health, not just cattle numbers
intervention_strategies: Pay farmers for pasture health metrics rather than just cattle output
Implement grazing fees that increase with total pasture usage
leverage_points.expected_impact: Makes individual rational decisions align with collective welfare

leverage_points.title: Implement Real-Time Pasture Health Monitoring
leverage_points.description: Create immediate, visible feedback about pasture degradation to reduce delay effects
intervention_strategies: Install monitoring systems that track grass health in real-time
Create visible dashboards showing pasture capacity utilization
Establish early warning systems for overgrazing
leverage_points.expected_impact: Reduces delay in feedback loops, making consequences more apparent

scenarios.title: Unrestricted Individual Optimization
scenarios.description: Both farmers continue to maximize individual cattle numbers without coordination

changes.change_description: Farmer A continues aggressive herd expansion based on short-term profit maximization
Farmer B matches or exceeds Farmer A's expansion to remain competitive

scenarios.predicted_outcomes: Rapid pasture degradation, eventual collapse of productivity, economic losses for both farmers despite initial gains

scenarios.title: Implement Cooperative Management
scenarios.description: Farmers agree to jointly manage the pasture within sustainable limits

changes.change_description: Total cattle count is managed collectively to stay within sustainable limits

scenarios.predicted_outcomes: Sustainable pasture health, stable long-term income for both farmers, avoided tragedy of commons

discussion_questions: Why do individually rational decisions lead to collectively irrational outcomes?
How do delays in feedback loops contribute to the tragedy of the commons?
What would motivate farmers to voluntarily limit their cattle numbers?
How might this pattern apply to other shared resources like fisheries or atmosphere?
What role does trust play in preventing commons tragedies?
key_insights: Individual optimization can lead to collective harm when resources are shared
Delays in negative feedback make short-term benefits seem more attractive than long-term costs
Tragedy of commons requires both competing reinforcing loops and weak/delayed balancing loops
Solutions require either changing incentive structures or creating collective governance
Trust and communication are essential for cooperative solutions to commons problems

common_misconceptions.misconception: The tragedy occurs because farmers are greedy or irrational
common_misconceptions.correction: The tragedy occurs because individually rational decisions lead to collectively harmful outcomes - the problem is structural, not personal

common_misconceptions.misconception: Government regulation is the only solution to commons problems
common_misconceptions.correction: Solutions can include privatization, collective self-governance, or changing economic incentives - regulation is one option among many

extension_activities: Research real-world examples of tragedy of commons and their solutions
Model different scenarios with varying numbers of farmers and pasture sizes
Explore how communication and trust affect cooperative solutions
Investigate how this pattern applies to climate change and global resources
